page.title: Using mutual funds and ETFs for short-term savings (5 years)

revision.text:
{{US|reason=harmful}} In investing, we make personal choices about how much [[Risk and return: an introduction|risk]] we are willing to take if we think we can get higher return in exchange. '''{{PAGENAME}}''' compares historical performance of similar funds that are appropriate for [[short-term]] savings. John Bogle, in his 1994 classic, ''Bogle on Mutual Funds'', suggested using a low-cost short-term treasury bond fund, with its government backed credit rating, as a prudent substitute for a money market fund for investment reserves distinct from savings and transaction account balances. (p.132 in the text) Volatility--fluctuations in value--are an important aspect of risk. In financial economics, volatility is often measured by a statistical value called the [[wikipedia:Standard deviation| standard deviation]], represented by the Greek letter ''sigma'' (σ). The standard deviation of mutual funds can be found on sites like [http://www.morningstar.com Morningstar] or [https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/fund-performance PortfolioVisualizer]. However, it is hard to relate this number to a practical question, like "how much risk would I be taking by putting money I need a year from now into a short-term bond fund instead of a money market fund?" This article tries to help with this kind of question. ==Overview== In this article, we calculate some other measures of risk by calculating what would have happened to an investment of $10,000, held for short periods of time, in a [[mutual fund]] or [[exchange-traded fund]] (ETF). You might do this in hope of making more than you would have made in a money market mutual fund, and accepting the possibility of sometimes making less. For funds and ETFs, calculations are based on data made publicly available free of charge from [https://www.morningstar.com/ Morningstar]. Data for the CPI is CPI-U, "CPI for All Urban Consumers," not seasonally adjusted, obtained from the [https://www.bls.gov/ Bureau of Labor Statistics]. The possibility of making less is depicted in two ways: 1) What ''percentage'' of the time would you have made less than in a money market fund? We chose VMMXX, the Vanguard Prime Money Market Fund, because it is one of the oldest money market fund and gave us a long period of comparison. We also show what percentage of the time you would have actually lost money--ended up with less than $10,000 at the end of the time period--and what percentage of time you would have failed to keep up with inflation. 2) It's important to know not just when a fund or ETF underperformed a money market mutual fund, but by how much. In the case of short-term funds, the losses, when they did occur, were so small that some might call them negligible To quantify this, we present two numbers. One is the average loss that occurred ''in those periods in which losses did occur;'' and the other is the largest loss that ever occurred within the body of data that was used. Notice that a high probability of underperforming may not be important at all. If two investments have the same return and volatility, but just fluctuate randomly with respect to each other, you would expect each of them to underperform the other about 50% of the time. We have chosen to present data going back for as far as Morningstar has data. As a result, there are two caveats. First, the data range shown for each fund is different and results for different funds cannot be directly compared. For example, the Vanguard Short-Term Treasury Fund, VFISX, beat VMMXX by an average of $117.10 while the Vanguard Short-Term Treasury ''Index'' fund, VGSH, only beat it by $33.17. But this is almost entirely due to VGSH's inception in 2009 versus VFISX's inception in 1991. If we restrict our view of VFISX to the same years as VGSH, the benefit for VFISX was only $44.05. Second, this underlines the problem with all historical data, which is that the present time--and thus the short-term future--may be quite different from the historical averages. ===Median and average (mean)=== We show both the average and the median for some key values. A reader requested this. We have a scattered group of values: the return from an investment over many different periods of time. To represent the center of such a group with a single number, we often calculate and average or mean. In the case here, when we are looking, for example, at losses, and only seeing "the tail of the distribution," the average may give the wrong impression because it's influenced by extreme values. The median is another measure, and represents the value that is halfway based on counting. If the median loss of an investment is $600, it means you had a 50% chance of losing more over $600 and a 50% chance of losing less than $600. ===Holding bond funds for the average "duration" of the fund=== A "duration" is a calculation based on bond math that gives a number of years, related to the bond's term but shorter. One interpretation of the duration is that it is the "point of indifference." It is too well known that when interest rates rise, bond values fall. What is less well known is that if a bond is held for its duration, at the end of that period of time it will have the same value regardless of what interest rates do, provided the yield curve moves in parallel. This does not apply to a bond ''fund'' because the bonds in a fund are all different "ages" at any given time, and because the yield curve doesn't move in parallel. So there are no guarantees, but, nevertheless, the duration tells us a holding period over which the fund is unlikely to lose money. This leads us to expect, for example, that "short-term" bond funds--like the Vanguard Short-Term Bond Index Fund, with a duration of 2.7 years--will sometimes lose money over periods of 6 or 12 months, but rarely lose money over periods of 5 years. This expectation is borne out by history. A bond fund may not lose money, in the sense of dollars, yet lose value to inflation. ===Holding stocks "for five years"=== Authorities advice against using stocks for money you will need in less than five years; '''Vanguard says ten.''' If you are considering using stocks for money you will need in five years, then you should familiarize yourself with the data for stocks held for five years. See [[Using mutual funds and ETFs for short-term savings (5 years)]]. Vanguard itself puts all of it stock funds in risk categories 4 and 5 and says "these funds may be appropriate for investors who have a long-term investment horizon '''(10 years or longer).'''" A few other authorities say: "Do not invest any money in stocks you will need in less than five years.”—William J. Bernstein, ''The Four Pillars of Investing''. “A rule of thumb in investing is that you should not invest money in stocks or stock funds that you will need in less than five years.”—Jack Brennan and Marta McCave, “Straight Talk on Investing.” “Owning stocks for the short term (less than five years) is foolish.”—''Kiplinger’s Personal Finance'', Nov, 2004. “Money you know you will need in the five to 10 years does not belong in stocks.”—Suze Orman, ''Suze Orman’s Action Plan''. Even Jim Cramer has said “If you need the money for something serious in the next four years, you cannot risk keeping it in stocks.”--Jim Cramer, ''Getting Back to Even''. ==Money market== ===BTFXX: BlackRock Liquidity=== {| class = "wikitable" style="width: 100%;" |+BTFXX: BlackRock Liquidity

page.title: How much do you lose to annual fees after many years?

revision.comment: /* Percentages lost to annual fees */ Removing empty cell borders improves table rendering.
revision.text:
'''"{{PAGENAMEBASE}}'''" shows how high [[Expense ratio|expense ratios]] can significantly reduce the amount of money you have in your portfolio. The longer you hold onto funds with high expense ratios, the less money you will have for retirement. The math works the same way for financial advisors who charge an Asset Under Management (AUM) fee. Whether you have an advisor who charges a 1% AUM fee, or a fund which has a 1% expense ratio, the effect on your portfolio is the same. ==Percentages lost to annual fees== Stated more precisely: *Assume that you buy an investment and do not touch it for n years. In other words, you do a "lump-sum" investment. * Assume that the investment has an annual fee f, expressed as a percentage. For example, a mutual fund might have an annual fee (an expense ratio) of 1%. *Assume that the annual fee is taken once per year, at the end of each year. This assumption is a simplification. For example, in reality, a mutual fund calculates its annual fee as a daily fee. *Temporarily imagine that the annual fee is zero and that your investment grows for n years. The final value of your investment---consider it as "100%." *What percentage of your investment do you lose to annual fees? The answer is 1 - (1 - f)^{n}. Later, we will prove the above formula. First, see the following table and examples. {{mw-datatable}} {| class="wikitable mw-datatable" style="border-style:none" |+How much do you lose to annual fees after many years? |- |style="background:none; border-style:none"| !0.05%!!0.10%!!0.15%!!0.20% |style="background:none; border-style:none"| !0.25%!!0.50%!!0.75%!!1.00%!!1.25%!!1.50%!!1.75% |style="background:none; border-style:none"| !2%!!3%!!4%!!5%!!6%!!7%!!8%!!9%!!10% |- !5 years ||{{0}}0%||{{0}}0%||{{0}}1%||{{0}}1%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||{{0}}1%||{{0}}2%||{{0}}4%||{{0}}5%||{{0}}6%||{{0}}7%||{{0}}8%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||10%||14%||18%||23%||27%||30%||34%||38%||41% |- !10 years ||{{0}}0%||{{0}}1%||{{0}}1%||{{0}}2%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||{{0}}2%||{{0}}5%||{{0}}7%||10%||12%||14%||16%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||18%||26%||34%||40%||46%||52%||57%||61%||65% |- !20 years ||{{0}}1%||{{0}}2%||{{0}}3%||{{0}}4%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||{{0}}5%||10%||14%||18%||22%||26%||30%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||33%||46%||56%||64%||71%||77%||81%||85%||88% |- !30 years ||{{0}}1%||{{0}}3%||{{0}}4%||{{0}}6%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||{{0}}7%||14%||20%||26%||31%||36%||41%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||45%||60%||71%||79%||84%||89%||92%||94%||96% |- !40 years ||{{0}}2%||{{0}}4%||{{0}}6%||{{0}}8%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||10%||18%||26%||33%||40%||45%||51%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||55%||70%||80%||87%||92%||95%||96%||98%||99% |- !50 years ||{{0}}2%||{{0}}5%||{{0}}7%||10%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||12%||22%||31%||39%||47%||53%||59%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||64%||78%||87%||92%||95%||97%||98%||99%||99% |- !60 years ||{{0}}3%||{{0}}6%||{{0}}9%||11%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||14%||26%||36%||45%||53%||60%||65%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||70%||84%||91%||95%||98% ||99%||99%||100%||100% |- !70 years ||{{0}}3%||{{0}}7%||10%||13%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||16%||30%||41%||51%||59%||65%||71%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||76%||88%||94%||97%||99%||99%||100%||100%||100% |- !80 years ||{{0}}4%||{{0}}8%||11%||15%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||18%||33%||45%||55%||63%||70%||76%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||80%||91%||96%||98%||99%||100%||100%||100%||100% |- !90 years ||{{0}}4%||{{0}}9%||13%||16%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||20%||36%||49%||60%||68%||74%||80%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||84%||94%||97%||99%||100%||100%||100%||100%||100% |- !100 years ||{{0}}5%||10%||14%||18%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||22%||39%||53%||63%||72%||78%||83%||style="background:none; border-style:none"| ||87%||95%||98%||99%||100%||100%||100%||100%||100% |} '''Example''': If you buy an investment with an annual fee of 0.10%, and do not touch the investment for 40 years, you lose 4% to annual fees. *The above percentage agrees with a result from user "Lobster," who started the following thread on [https://www.bogleheads.org/ Bogleheads] on 2017-04-20: [https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=10&t=217026 Visualizing the devastating impact of fees]. User "Lobster" linked to a [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1e84iEblhPhdtWuOCR25v1M96ug6IHwGU8FelxJ8M-vY/edit#gid=1654711040 Google Sheets spreadsheet] which has a column chart and which has a percentage of 3.92%. *Note that 3.92% = 1 - (1 - 0.10%)^{40}. '''Example''': If you buy an investment with an annual fee of 2%, and do not touch the investment for 10 years, you lose 18% to annual fees. * The above percentage agrees with a result from Mr. Richard A. Howard, on his web site [https://buyupside.com/calculators/feesdec07.htm buyupside]. We boldface the important text: :{{quotation|Assume that you invested $10,000, held it for '''10 years''' at a 6 percent annual rate of return. Paying no fees, you would have $17,908.48. '''With a two percent annual fee,''' you would have $14,632.53, '''an 18.29 percent reduction''' due to fees.}} *Note that 18.29% = 1 - (1 - 2%)^{10}. '''Example''': If you buy an investment with an annual fee of 2%, and do not touch the investment for 30 years, you lose 45% to annual fees. *The above percentage agrees with a result from Mr. Richard A. Howard, on his web site [https://buyupside.com/calculators/feesdec07.htm buyupside]. We boldface the important text: :{{quotation|Now take the same $10,000 and hold it for '''30 years''' at 6 percent return. With no fees, you would have $57,434.91. '''With a two percent annual fee,''' you would accumulate $31,329.84, '''a 45.45 percent reduction.''' So the two percent annual fee cut your total return almost in half!}} *Note that 45.45% = 1 - (1 - 2%)^{30}. '''Example''': If you buy an investment with an annual fee of 2%, and do not touch the investment for 50 years, you lose 64% to annual fees. *The above percentage agrees approximately with a result from Mr. John ("Jack") C. Bogle, the founder of [https://about.vanguard.com/ Vanguard], in an [https://www.cfr.org/event/conversation-john-c-bogle interview] on 2017-11-28. We boldface the important text: :{{quotation|And so if you’re in the market for a lifetime, and you earn a—don’t hold me to this—I think I just did maybe '''50 years.''' And you earn, let’s say, a 7 percent return, you’ll end up with, say, $30 per dollar, something like that, invested. And if you do it and earn 5 percent, that’s the 7 percent in the market, less than '''2 percent playing the game,''' you end up with $10. So '''you’ve given up two-thirds of your return'''—$30 versus $10.}} *Note that 64% = 1 - (1 - 2%)^{50}. The following examples do not use the above table, but they use the formula which we mentioned earlier. '''Example''': If you buy an investment with an annual fee of 2%, and do not touch the investment for 25 years, you lose 40% to annual fees. *The above percentage agrees with a result from [https://about.vanguard.com/ Vanguard] on their web page [https://investor.vanguard.com/investing/how-to-invest/impact-of-costs Don't let high costs eat away your returns]. We boldface the important text: :{{quotation|Imagine you have $100,000 invested. If the account earned 6% a year for the next '''25 years''' and had no costs or fees, you'd end up with about $430,000. If, on the other hand, you paid 2% a year in costs, after 25 years you'd only have about $260,000. That's right: '''The 2% you paid every year would wipe out almost 40% of your final account value.''' 2% doesn't sound so small anymore, does it?}} *Note that 40% = 1 - (1 - 2%)^{25}. '''Example''': If you buy an investment with an annual fee of 2.5%, and do not touch the investment for 65 years, you lose 81% to annual fees. *The above percentage agrees approximately with a result from Mr. John ("Jack") C. Bogle, the founder of [https://about.vanguard.com/ Vanguard], in an [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/retirement/interviews/bogle.html interview] on 2006-02-07 with the documentary program [https://www.pbs.org/show/frontline/ Frontline]. We boldface the important text: :{{quotation|If you invest $1,000 at the beginning of that time and earn 8 percent, that $1,000 will grow in that '''65-year period''' to around $140,000. Now, '''the financial system''' -- the mutual fund system in this case -- '''will take about two and a half percentage points''' out of that return, so you will have a gross return of 8 percent, a net return of 5.5 percent, and your $1,000 will grow to approximately $30,000. One hundred ten thousand dollars goes to the financial system and $30,000 to you, the investor. Think about that. That means '''the financial system''' put up zero percent of the capital and took zero percent of the risk and '''got almost 80 percent of the return,''' and you, the investor in this long time period, an investment lifetime, put up 100 percent of the capital, took 100 percent of the risk, and got only a little bit over 20 percent of the return.}} *Note that 81% = 1 - (1 - 2.5%)^{65}. ==Formula proof== Below, we prove the formula which we mentioned earlier. * Assume that you buy an investment and do not touch it for n years. *Assume that the investment has an annual fee f, expressed as a percentage. *Assume that the annual fee is taken once per year, at the end of each year. *Temporarily imagine that the annual fee is zero and that your investment grows for n years. The final value of your investment---consider it as "100%." *What percentage of your investment do you lose to annual fees? The answer is 1 - (1 - f)^{n}. Proof. *Let P be your principal at the start of year 1. *Let r_{i} be the investment's annual return in year i. * At the end of year 1, you will have P(1 + r_{1})(1 - f). *At the end of year 2, you will have P(1 + r_{1})(1 - f) \times (1 + r_{2})(1 - f). *At the end of year 3, you will have P(1 + r_{1})(1 - f) \times (1 + r_{2})(1 - f) \times (1 + r_{3})(1 - f). *At the end of year n, you will have P(1 + r_{1})(1 - f) \times (1 + r_{2})(1 - f) \times (1 + r_{3})(1 - f) \times \cdots \times (1 + r_{n})(1 - f). *Let I be the last value above. I stands for "investment value." *Temporarily imagine that the annual fee is zero: f = 0. Substitute this into the expression for I, getting P(1 - r_{1})(1 - r_{2})(1 - r_{3}) ... (1 - r_{n}). *Let M be the last value above. M stands for "max value of investment." Assume that M is not zero. Later, we will divide by M. *Note that I/M = (1 - f)(1 - f)(1 - f) ... (1 - f) = (1 - f)^{n}. This is the percentage of your investment that you keep. *Therefore the percentage of your investment that you lose to annual fees is 1 - I/M = 1 - (1 - f)^{n}. ==Generalized formula== We can generalize our above formula. We allow the years to have possibly different annual fees. The formula statement becomes: *... *Assume that the investment has n annual fees f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3}, ..., f_{n}, where each fee is a percentage. *... *What percentage of your investment do you lose to annual fees? The answer is 1 - (1 - f_{1})(1 - f_{2})(1 - f_{3}) ... (1 - f_{n}). The proof of the generalized formula is similar to the proof of the original formula. ==More related work == On 2011-10-28, in the Vanguard blog post [https://web.archive.org/web/20161110064941/http://vanguardblog.com/2011/10/28/stopping-the-silent-killer-of-returns/ Stopping the silent killer of returns], Dr. John Ameriks posted a table, which we recreate below. Most of his values agree with ours, if we ignore the minus signs. However, he used a different formula: 1-(1+c)^{-T}, where c is an annual fee (possibly "c" stands for "cost"), and T is the number of years (possibly "T" stands for "time"). This formula is discussed in a thread on [https://www.bogleheads.org/ Bogleheads] which was started by user "Lobster" on 2017-04-20: [https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=10&t=217026 Visualizing the devastating impact of fees]. In that thread, users "Kevin M" and "#Cruncher" ("number cruncher") think that this formula is related to how mutual funds calculate the annual fee as a daily fee. '''Cumulative impact of fees on ending wealth at various time horizons''' {| class="wikitable" |+Annual fee rate |- !Fee!!0.10%!!0.25%!!0.50%!!1.00%!!2.00%!!3.00% |- |3 years||{{0}}−0.3%||{{0}}−0.7%||{{0}}−1.5%||{{0}}−2.9%||{{0}}−5.8%||{{0}}−8.5% |- |5 years||{{0}}−0.5%||{{0}}−1.2%||{{0}}−2.5%||{{0}}−4.9%||{{0}}−9.4%||−13.7% |- |10 years||{{0}}−1.0%||{{0}}−2.5%||{{0}}−4.9%||{{0}}−9.5%||−18.0%||−25.6% |- |20 years||{{0}}−2.0%||{{0}}−4.9%||{{0}}−9.5%||−18.0%||−32.7%||−44.6% |- |30 years||{{0}}−3.0%||{{0}}−7.2%||−13.9%||−25.8%||−44.8%||−58.8% |- |40 years||{{0}}−3.9%||{{0}}−9.5%||−18.1%||−32.8% ||−54.7%||−69.3% |- |} On 2018-02-26, on the blog post [https://www.wallstreetphysician.com/much-total-returns-lost-fees/ How Much Of Your Total Returns Are Lost To Fees?], blogger "Wall Street Physician" posted a table, which we recreate below. The values differ somewhat from ours, possibly because of differences in rounding, or because of other reasons. {| class="wikitable" |+Fees
(Calculations assume 8% return) |- !Fee!!1%!!2%!!3%!!4% |- |10 years||{{0}}9%||17%||25%||31% |- |20 years||17%||31%||43%||53% |- |30 years||24%||43%||57%||68% |- |40 years||31%||53%||68%||78% |- |} {{Mutual funds}} [[Category:Mutual funds]]

revision.comment: /* Tilting using adaptive asset allocation */ show the calculations for updated weights and normalized allocation
revision.text:
The '''{{PAGENAME}}''' is a portfolio proposed by [[William F. Sharpe]]. It consists of global stocks and bonds, held in [[Free-float methodology|free-float]] market proportions.<ref name=RISMAT-7>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Retirement Income Scenario Matrices 7. The Market Portfolio|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/RISMAT-7.pdf|publisher=Stanford University (Creative Commons)|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref>
== Components ==
There is currently no single retail fund that implements a World Bond/Stock (WBS) portfolio in the way described by Sharpe. To address this, he has suggested a four-fund proxy<ref name=RISMAT-7/><ref name=4-Fund-Proxy>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=The Four-fund Proxy for the World Bond Stock Fund|url=https://retirementincomeanalysis.blogspot.com/2019/08/the-four-fund-proxy-for-wold-bond-stock.html|date=August 2019|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> and also a two-fund proxy<ref name=2-Fund-Proxy>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=A Two-fund Proxy for the World Bond Stock Fund|url=https://retirementincomeanalysis.blogspot.com/2019/09/a-two-fund-proxy-for-world-bond-stock.html|date=September 2019|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> for WBS consisting of established Vanguard index funds.
A four-fund proxy for WBS consists of:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund !! Asset class |- | VTSAX (or VTI) || US stocks |- | VTIAX (or VXUS) || Ex-US stocks |- | VBTLX (or BND) || USD bonds |- | VTABX (or BNDX) || Ex-USD bonds |- |}
A two-fund proxy for WBS consists of:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund !! Asset class |- | VT || Global stocks |- | BNDW || Global bonds |- |}
Of course, it is also possible to implement something similar with non-Vanguard funds.
== Allocations ==
The index funds used by the WBS proxies described above are held in proportion to their free-float market capitalization. That requires calculating the market capitalization of the index that each fund tracks. This is done by taking each index's market capitalization listed in its most recent factsheet, and then projecting that forward by the change in the fund's adjusted closing prices between the factsheet's publishing date and the current date.
<math> \mathrm{IndexMarketCap}_\mathrm{Current} = \mathrm{IndexMarketCap}_\mathrm{Factsheet} \times \frac{\mathrm{TrackingFundPrice}_\mathrm{Current}}{\mathrm{TrackingFundPrice}_{\mathrm{FactsheetDate}}} </math>
Note: VBTLX/BND, VTABX/BNDX, and BNDW track Bloomberg indices which do not publish their market capitalization numbers. Sharpe has suggested that FTSE indexes (for example, WorldBIG) could substitute.<ref name=RISMAT-7/><ref name=4-Fund-Proxy/>
=== Example ===
Here is an example of the allocation calculations as of June 15, 2025:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund ! Asset class ! Tracked index ! Index factsheet market cap ! Index factsheet date ! Adjusted closing price on factsheet date ! Latest adjusted closing price (June 15, 2025) ! Projected market cap (June 15, 2025) ! Allocation (June 15, 2025) |- | VT | Global stocks | FTSE Global All Cap Index | $90.42T | May 30, 2025 | $123.37 | $124.95 | $91.58T (= $90.42T * $124.95 / $123.37) | 62.43% (= $91.58T / ($55.08T + $91.58T)) |- | BNDW | Global bonds | FTSE WorldBIG (substitute for Bloomberg index) | $54.93T | May 31, 2025 | $68.58 | $68.77 | $55.08T (= $54.93T * $68.77 / $68.58) | 37.57% (= $55.08T / ($55.08T + $91.58T)) |- |}
=== Current allocations ===
Here are the current allocations for the four-fund proxy, updated in real time:
{| border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; |- |{{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=2PACX-1vQShEGnLTHNk2_zgHWTiReXADEhmNvLR8SIaTsdGTdQJaa_F9ESrbo8bcsP0XEsVlBFtGEbjqUMO7g_ |oid=1905516517 |width=450 |height=280 }} |- |Source: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VFfGgf-oscxsnyjHLsdIGNa5WfxI00XG_51xxr5VUn4/edit#gid=717958008 GMP: Global Market Portfolio] |}
Here are the current allocations for the two-fund proxy, updated in real time:
{| border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; |- |{{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=2PACX-1vQShEGnLTHNk2_zgHWTiReXADEhmNvLR8SIaTsdGTdQJaa_F9ESrbo8bcsP0XEsVlBFtGEbjqUMO7g_ |oid=912172076 |width=450 |height=280 }} |- |Source: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VFfGgf-oscxsnyjHLsdIGNa5WfxI00XG_51xxr5VUn4/edit#gid=717958008 GMP: Global Market Portfolio] |}
Note: The total allocation to VTI and VXUS in the four-fund proxy might not precisely equal the VT allocation in the two-fund proxy. This is because VTI tracks a [[CRSP equity indexes|CRSP]] index which differs slightly from the [[FTSE Group|FTSE]] index that VT tracks.
== Rebalancing == {{See also|Rebalancing}}
The World Bond/Stock (WBS) portfolio holds each individual asset (that is, individual stock or bond) in proportion to its free-float market capitalization. Equivalently, it holds the same fraction of each asset’s free-float shares outstanding. That is, '''(shares held) / (free-float shares outstanding)''' is the same for every individual asset.
Framing WBS this way shows that rebalancing is needed only when an asset’s free-float supply changes the fraction of shares held (for example, new issuances, buybacks, or redemptions).
Conversely, events like price changes and dividend payments do ''not'' require rebalancing since they leave the fraction of shares held unchanged. As a result, WBS requires less frequent rebalancing than traditional fixed-weight portfolios (for example, a 60/40 stock/bond mix), which must rebalance whenever asset prices change.
If WBS assets are held through a ''single'' index fund, the fund handles rebalancing internally. But if assets are split across ''multiple funds'' (for example, stocks in VT and bonds in BNDW), their underlying free-float supply may change at different rates. This causes the share fractions held by the different funds to drift apart, requiring occasional manual rebalancing between the funds to realign them.
== Adjusting for personal circumstances ==
The World Bond/Stock portfolio mirrors the holdings of the average publicly invested portfolio, thereby taking on average investment risk and producing average return.<ref name=Arithmetic>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=The Arithmetic of Active Management|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/art/active/active.htm|publisher=Association for Investment Management and Research|date=February 1991|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> This makes it a good default strategy.
Nevertheless, Sharpe notes that someone may justifiably deviate from this strategy to adjust for personal circumstances.<ref name=Adjust>{{Cite web|author=Charles Rotblut, William F. Sharpe|title=Allocate by Market Weight (And Adjust for Personal Circumstances)|url=https://www.aaii.com/files/PDF/9314_allocate-by-market-weight-and-adjust-for-personal-circumstances.pdf|publisher=American Association of Individual Investors|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> Adjustments discussed by Sharpe include: * '''Adding a riskless asset.''' For example, using certain inflation-adjusted investments (like [[Treasury Inflation Protected Security|TIPS]]) to cover a portion of real expenses.<ref name=RISMAT-6>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Retirement Income Analysis with scenario matrices, Chapter 6. Inflation-Protected Investments|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/RISMAT-6.pdf|publisher=Stanford University (Creative Commons)|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> * '''Tilting asset allocations.''' For example, adjusting the stock/bond ratio to account for factors like [[Human capital|human capital]].<ref name=Adjust/>
=== Tilting using adaptive asset allocation ===
Sharpe proposes Adaptive Asset Allocation Policies, which allow asset class tilting while still remaining anchored to the dynamics of the WBS portfolio.<ref name=AAAP>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Adaptive Asset Allocation Policies |url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/aaap/wfsaaap.pdf|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> This enables customization while continuously adapting to changes in the relative risk between asset classes.
It works as follows. Start with a desired initial allocation. Then update each asset class weight using:
<math> \mathrm{UpdatedWeight} = \mathrm{CurrentMarketWeight} \times \frac{\mathrm{InitialDesiredWeight}}{\mathrm{InitialMarketWeight}} </math>
Finally, normalize the updated weights to get the new allocation. For example:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund ! Asset class ! Initial desired weight ! Initial market weight ! Current market weight ! Updated weight ! Normalized allocation |- | VT | Global stocks | 80% | 60% | 55% | 73.33% (= 55% * 80/60) | 76.52% (= 73.33 / (73.33 + 22.50)) |- | BNDW | Global bonds | 20% | 40% | 45% | 22.50% (=45% * 20/40) | 23.48% (= 22.50 / (73.33 + 22.50)) |- |}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/ Retirement Income Analysis With Scenario Matrices (RISMAT)], William F. Sharpe, viewed August 20, 2017. ** [https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/RISMAT-7.pdf Chapter 7. The Market Portfolio] * "[https://youtu.be/XsXOLZ9U7jI?t=2344 In Pursuit of the Perfect Portfolio: William F. Sharpe]." ''[http://youtube.com YouTube]'', uploaded by [https://www.youtube.com/@mitlaboratoryforfinanciale6144 MIT Laboratory for Financial Engineering], 26 May, 2016. * [https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/aaap/wfsaaap.pdf Adaptive Asset Allocation Policies], William F. Sharpe, November 2009. * {{Forum post|t=207804|title=Bill Sharpe's preferred portfolio}} * [https://www.forbes.com/sites/phildemuth/2014/07/30/meet-the-global-market-portfolio-the-optimal-portfolio-for-the-average-investor/#21da5d7370d1 Meet the Global Market Portfolio], Phil DeMuth, July 30, 2014. Forbes. * {{Forum link|t=456731|title=Proposed overhaul of World Bond/Stock Portfolio wiki page|author=djm2001|date=June 16, 2025}}

page.title: Vanguard funds: life strategy funds vs target retirement funds

revision.text:
{{US|reason=none}}
Both [[Vanguard target retirement funds|Vanguard Target Retirement Funds]] and [[Vanguard LifeStrategy Funds]] can be used as all-in-one portfolios. This article addresses the similarities and differences between the two series of funds.
{{Notice|Vanguard has an article about [https://personal.vanguard.com/us/content/Funds/FundsVanguardFundsLifeStrategyTargetCompare.jsp comparing Vanguard LifeStrategy Funds and Vanguard Target Retirement Funds]. In addition to what Vanguard already mentioned, you may consider the following.}}
==Minimum investment== The target retirement funds have a minimum investment of $1,000 for opening an account; this makes it easier for small investors, just beginning their investment careers, to begin an investment program. The LifeStrategy funds have a higher $3,000 minimum investment requirement.
== Control over asset allocation == If you selected a target retirement fund based on its current asset allocation, not the target year, you may find that the fund shifts its asset allocation either too soon or too late. For example, suppose you plan to retire in 2030, but you think the 85% stocks 15% allocation in Vanguard Target Retirement 2030 Fund is too aggressive for your need, ability and willingness to take risk. Instead, you like the allocation in Vanguard Target Retirement 2015 Fund, which currently invests approximately 65% in stocks and 35% in bonds. If you invest in Target Retirement 2015, however, at some time close to 2015, the fund will shift its allocation more conservatively, while you are still at least 15 years away from your planned retirement. Or if you'd like to be more aggressive and invest in Target Retirement 2035 while you plan to retire in 2015, you may find the allocation in Target Retirement 2035 not shifting when you need a less aggressive allocation.
If you invest in a LifeStrategy fund, this problem can be mitigated. You pick an allocation and change your allocation only when you want to. Alternatively, you can still invest in a Target Retirement fund but you have to watch for the allocation changes every year or every few years. If the allocation no longer suits you, switch to a different Target Retirement fund. This is best implemented in a tax deferred or tax free (Roth) account because there are no tax implications for switching. It somewhat defeats the "set it and forget it" appeal of a Target Retirement fund, but it's a good compromise between simplicity and maintaining your desired asset allocation.
== Short-term asset allocation swings == From inception in 1994 through the fourth quarter of 2011, all LifeStrategy funds had an allocation to Vanguard Asset Allocation Fund. The underlying asset allocation in Vanguard Asset Allocation Fund changed frequently in the short-term. This caused swings to the asset allocation of LifeStrategy funds. For example, when Vanguard Asset Allocation Fund changed from 60% in stocks to 100% in stocks, LifeStrategy Moderate Growth Fund's allocation also changed from 60% in stocks to 70% in stock.
Vanguard announced a revision in the LifeStragegy funds allocations in a September 30, 2011 web posting<ref>[https://personal.vanguard.com/us/insights/article/fund-announcementB-09302011 LifeStrategy Funds to adopt all-index approach]</ref> and instituted an additional change in 2013, adding [[Developed market bonds|international bonds]] to the portfolios.The new allocations consist of four broad-based index funds:
*Vanguard Total Market Index Fund *Vanguard Total International Index Fund *Vanguard Total Bond Market II Index Fund *Vanguard Total International Bond Index Fund
==Taxes == Historical data indicate that if you held the funds in a taxable account (not normally recommended for either one, but the simplicity may be worth the tax costs), the target retirement funds were slightly better options. The LifeStrategy funds held the Vanguard Asset Allocation Fund, which can realize capital gains as it changes its allocation. The revised post 2011 fund choices for the LifeStrategy funds will mean that the LifeStrategy funds can be expected to realize fewer short term and long term gains going forward.
==International allocation== All target retirement funds and LifeStrategy funds have 40% of the fund's equity allocation in international stocks. The actual portfolio weighting of international stocks will depend on the overall strategic equity allocation of the fund (the range will fall between ~12% and ~36% international stock for target retirement funds<ref> See [[Vanguard target retirement funds#Detailed fund allocations]]</ref>; and fall between 8% and 32% for the LifeStrategy funds<ref> See [[Vanguard LifeStrategy Funds#Fund allocations]]</ref>.
The international bond fund represents 30% of the fixed income allocation of LifeStrategy and most target retirement funds. The Income and near-term Target Retirement funds (in the next 10 years) have slightly less international bond allocation due to an increasing allocation to short-term TIPS along the glide path<ref> See [[Glide paths#Target retirement funds glide paths]]</ref>.
==[[Treasury Inflation Protected Security|TIPs]]== Some target retirement funds (2020, 2015, and [https://investor.vanguard.com/mutual-funds/profile/VTINX Income]) include [[Treasury Inflation Protected Security|TIPS]] while none of the LifeStrategy funds includes [[Treasury Inflation Protected Security|TIPS]].
==Cost== The target retirement funds and LifeStrategy funds have similar expense ratios.
==History== LifeStrategy funds have longer history. They were launched on 30 Sep 1994. Target retirement funds were launched on 27 Oct 2003 or later.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Balanced funds}} {{Mutual funds}} [[Category:Vanguard]] [[Category:Balanced funds]]

{{US|reason=harmful}}
'''{{PAGENAME}}''' are all-in-one funds that automatically adjust the asset mix of stocks, bonds and cash according to a selected time frame.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/target-date_fund.asp| title=What Is a Target-Date Fund? Risk Tolerance and Example| publisher=Investopedia| date=October 2, 2022| accessdate=August 20, 2023}}</ref> The funds become more conservative over time, creating a [[Glide paths|glide path]] by gradually shifting their asset allocations from equities and into fixed income. Target date funds are useful for retirement saving, and also as age-adjusted portfolios for [[529|college savings plans]].
Target date funds are designed for people who want simple investment management. These funds make assumptions about their potential investors; one of which is [[Asset allocation|asset allocation]], an important investor decision. Although target date funds are designed for investors retiring in a given year (approximately), they are also useful for markedly different retirement dates or for other goals, depending on your particular objectives and risk tolerance.
Target date funds have become increasingly popular over time. Many corporate retirement plans now offer these funds, often as default investment options. Target date fund total assets exceeded $4 trillion in 2024.<ref name=":1">[https://401kspecialistmag.com/tdfs-top-4-trillion-mark-in-2024-morningstar/#:~:text=Vanguard%20remains%20top%20TDF%20asset,billion%20and%20$16.8%20billion%2C%20respectively. 401kSpecialist - TDFs Top $4 Trillion Mark in 2024: Morningstar]</ref> The top five target date fund companies account for approximately 80% of the market:<ref>[https://marketing.morningstar.com/content/cs-assets/v3/assets/blt9415ea4cc4157833/bltd2006cbdc6c250c8/683a0a55b705e0691463f1a4/Target-Date_Landscape_2025_(2).pdf Morningstar - 2025 Target-Date Fund Landscape]</ref>
* Vanguard 37% * ﻿﻿Fidelity 14% * ﻿﻿T. Rowe Price 11% * ﻿﻿BlackRock 10% * ﻿﻿Capital Group 8% * ﻿﻿Remaining TDFs 20%
Different providers operate target date funds in different ways. The funds are often structured as funds-of-funds. Some providers only use index funds in their target date funds; others include a (large) portion of active funds. The fund expense ratios can differ widely between providers. However as of 2024 the average expense ratio has decreased to 0.29%, which represents an almost 50% decrease over 10 years.<ref>[https://marketing.morningstar.com/content/cs-assets/v3/assets/blt9415ea4cc4157833/bltd2006cbdc6c250c8/683a0a55b705e0691463f1a4/Target-Date_Landscape_2025_(2).pdf Morningstar - 2025 Target-Date Fund Landscape]</ref> Passive funds account for 53% of TDF assets. As of 2024, [[Collective Investment Trusts|collective investment trusts]] have become the most common holder of target date funds, with 52% of total target date fund assets. [https://www.investor.gov/introduction-investing/investing-basics/glossary/collective-investment-trust-cit Collective investment trusts] are only available to qualified retirement plans and typically have lower expense ratios than mutual funds.
==Target date fund components==
Target date funds are typically comprised of stocks, bonds and cash. On the stocks side, typically there is a combination of a broad US equity fund and an ex-US / International fund. The allocation of each tends to vary between fund companies, but the allocation percents roughly approximate their respective global market weights, with US allocations ranging from 56%-70%.<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/why-more-target-date-funds-are-underweighting-us-stocks-today Why More Target-Date Funds Are Underweighting US Stocks Today]</ref>
On the bond side, typically you find a bond index fund including mix of US [[Treasury bond|Treasury bonds]] and [[corporate bonds]]. Also, some fund companies (such as Vanguard) include an allocation of [[international bonds]].<ref>[https://institutional.vanguard.com/investment/strategies/tdf-construction.html Vanguard-Target-date fund portfolio construction]</ref>
Finally, some fund companies also include [[Treasury Inflation Protected Securities]] (TIPS), with an increasing allocation of TIPS as the fund approaches the applicable target date. Cash allocations are typically low but grow as the target date is approached.
==Asset allocations - glide path== Actual asset allocations of target date funds vary by fund company, but they typically approximate each other in rough terms. Funds with distant target retirement dates are almost all stocks, and funds with a target date retirement within the next few years will have a sizable portion of bonds. As the retirement date approaches the stock allocation decreases and the bond allocation increases, eventually ending up at a fixed lower equity percent some number of years after the target retirement date. This pattern of sequentially decreasing equity allocations and ending up at terminal fixed equity allocation is commonly referred to as a [[glide path]]. Most target date funds offer retirement dates in five year increments.
Using Vanguard Target date funds as an example, in 2025, the Vanguard Target Retirement 2065 fund has a stock allocation of approximately 90% stocks and 10% bonds and cash.<ref name=":0">[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vlxvx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2065 Fund VLXVX]</ref> The stock allocation of the fund series starts at 90% and decreases to 30% seven years after the target date year, while the bond/cash allocation increases correspondingly.<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/vanguard-target-retirement-series Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement Series]</ref> The following are the 2025 fund allocations:
* 2070: 90% / 10%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vsvnx/portfolio Vanguard Target Retirement 2070 Fund VSVNX]</ref> * 2065: 90% / 10%<ref name=":0" /> * 2060: 90% / 10%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vttsx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2060 Fund VTTSX]</ref> * 2055: 90% / 10%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vffvx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2055 Fund VFFVX]</ref> * 2050: 90% / 10%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vfifx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2050 Fund VFIFX]</ref> * 2045: 83% / 17%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vtivx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2045 Fund VTIVX]</ref> * 2040: 75% / 25%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vforx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2040 Fund VFORX]</ref> * 2035: 68% / 32%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vtthx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2035 Fund VTTHX]</ref> * 2030: 60% / 40%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vthrx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2030 Fund VTHRX]</ref> * 2025: 50% / 50%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vttvx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2025 Fund VTTVX]</ref> * 2020: 36% / 64%<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vtwnx/portfolio Vanguard Target Retirement 2020 Fund VTWNX]</ref>
Target Date Income Fund: 30% / 70%.<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vtinx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement Income Fund VTINX]</ref>
Throughout the series the equity portion maintains a constant 60% US / 40% ex-US allocation. The bond portion maintains a 70% US / 30% ex-US allocation. Once the retirement date year is reached an allocation of short term TIPS is added to the bond allocation.
Drilling down into other allocation components, using Vanguard Target Date 2025 and 2040 as examples (as of July 2025):
{| class="wikitable" |+ Vanguard Target Retirement 2025 holdings<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vttvx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2025 Fund VTTVX]</ref> (as of 2025) !Holdings !% Portfolio weight |- !Vanguard Total Stock Mkt Idx Instl Pls |30.46 |- !Vanguard Total Intl Stock Index Inv |20.18 |- !Vanguard Total Bond Market II Idx Inv |28.91 |- !Vanguard Total Intl Bd II Idx Insl |12.18 |- !Vanguard Shrt-Term Infl-Prot Sec Idx Adm |7.56 |- !Other |0.71 |}
{| class="wikitable" |+ Vanguard Target Retirement 2040 holdings<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vforx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2040 Fund VFORX]</ref> (as of 2025) !Holdings !% Portfolio weight |- !Vanguard Total Stock Mkt Idx Instl Pls |45.82 |- !Vanguard Total Intl Stock Index Inv |30.18 |- !Vanguard Total Bond Market II Idx Inv |16.55 |- !Vanguard Total Intl Bd II Idx Insl |6.88 |- !Other |0.56 |} Below is a graphic from [https://www.morningstar.com/funds/target-date-funds-retirement-income-closer-look Morningstar] comparing the [[glide path]] of Vanguard Target date funds to others and the industry average:
:{| style = |+'''Figure 1: Target Date Glidepaths''' |- |[[File:Target date fund glidepaths.jpg|left]] |- | Source: Morningstar. |}
==Selecting an adequate target date fund== The Department of Labor recommends that investors consider the following factors when selecting a target date fund:<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.dol.gov/ebsa/pdf/TDFinvestorbulletin.pdf| title=Investor Bulletin: Target Date Retirement Funds| publisher=Department of Labor| date=May 6, 2010| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216211307/https://www.dol.gov/sites/default/files/ebsa/about-ebsa/our-activities/resource-center/fact-sheets/TDFInvestorBulletin.pdf| archive-date=February 16, 2017}}</ref>
*Consider your investment style. Do you want to play an active role in managing your investments, or do you prefer the more hands-off approach of a target date fund? Keep in mind, however, that even with a target date fund, it is important to monitor the fund’s investments over time. *Look at the fund’s prospectus to see where the fund will invest your money. Do you understand the strategy and risks of the fund, or of any underlying mutual funds held as investments? *Understand how the investments will change over time. Are you comfortable with the fund’s investment mix over time? In particular, make sure you understand when the fund will reach its most conservative investment mix and whether that will occur at or after the target date. Does your level of risk tolerance match how aggressive or conservative it is? *Take into account when you will access the money in the fund. How does the fund’s investment mix at the target date and thereafter fit with your plans for the future, whether they are to withdraw your money at retirement, or to continue to invest? *Examine the fund’s fees. Do you understand the costs for both the target date fund and for any mutual funds in which the target date fund invests?
When choosing a fund, the [[Bogleheads]] recommendation is to ignore the fund's date. Instead, determine the amount of risk you are willing to tolerate, and then work backwards to find a fund that matches the chosen stock/bond allocation. You may be surprised to find a large discrepancy between your planned retirement date and the fund's target date. Remember that the fund does not know you, or your personal [[risk tolerance]].
==Target date fund advantages== ===Diversification=== With the purchase of a single fund, you gain exposure to a broad portfolio of US and international stocks, and thousands of US and international bonds. These funds are excellent choices if you do not have enough to meet the initial minimum investments for purchasing separate funds.
===Asset allocation on autopilot=== Professionals manage the [[asset allocation]], and it changes automatically as the target date gets closer.
Most investors tend to prefer a declining stock allocation glidepath as they approach and go through retirement in order to reduce risk at the point of withdrawing from their portfolios. Target date funds provide an automatic “set and forget” glidepath such that investors don’t have to worry about making continual de-risking adjustments to their portfolio as they approach and navigate retirement.
Target date funds also provide ongoing rebalancing between asset classes, saving investors the time and effort needed to make such periodic adjustments.
===Simplicity===
For many, only having to manage one fund is easier than deciding on and managing a multiple fund portfolio. This is one reason target date funds are frequently found in employer retirement plans such as 401ks.
===Low expenses===
Most of the major brokerages now offer index fund versions of target date funds with expense ratios only slightly higher than that of comparable individual component index funds. As of 12/31/2024 the average Vanguard Target date expense ratio was 0.08%.<ref>[https://investor.vanguard.com/investment-products/mutual-funds/target-retirement-funds Vanguard Target Retirement Funds]</ref> Fidelity Freedom Index Target date funds have ratios of approximately 0.12%.<ref>[https://www.fidelity.com/bin-public/060_www_fidelity_com/documents/SHDOCS/FDKLX/hosts/sh_comm_pmqa.002216.RETAIL_pdf.pdf Fidelity Freedom® Index Funds]</ref> Some employer plans may have even lower expense offerings with “institutional” or [https://www.investor.gov/introduction-investing/investing-basics/glossary/collective-investment-trust-cit collective investment trust] versions.
==Criticisms== Although target date funds provide very simple diversification for their shareholders, there are reasonable criticisms of them.
===Mismatch between target retirement year and asset allocation choice=== The funds set an asset allocation for a given target date either for education or retirement. Not everybody wants the same allocation, even if they will retire in the same year or target the same year for education expenses. You might find the fund's allocation for your target year is either too aggressive or too conservative.
If you select a target date fund by its current asset allocation, and not the target year, you may find that the fund shifts its asset allocation either too soon or too late.
For example, suppose it is 2025 and you plan to retire in 2045 but you think the approximately 85% stocks 15% bond<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vtivx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2045 Fund VTIVX]</ref> allocation in Vanguard Target Retirement 2045 Fund is too aggressive for your need, ability and willingness to take risk. Instead, you like the allocation in Vanguard Target Retirement 2030 Fund, approximately 60% in stocks and 40% in bonds.<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/xnas/vthrx/portfolio Morningstar - Vanguard Target Retirement 2030 Fund VTHRX]</ref> If you invest in Target Retirement 2030, however, at some time close to 2030, the fund will shift its allocation more conservatively, while you are still at least 15 years away from your planned retirement.
On the other hand, if you would like to be more aggressive and invest in Target Retirement 2050 while you plan to retire in 2035, you may find the allocation in Target Retirement 2050 not shifting when you need a less aggressive allocation after you retire.
In addition to the bond allocation, some investors may prefer a different equity allocation between U.S. and ex-U.S. stocks. As of 2025, target date funds tend to approximate global market weights, with roughly 60% in U.S. and 40% ex-U.S. If you want to tilt one way or another a target date fund may not be the best choice.
===Tax inefficiency of target date retirement funds=== Target date retirement funds include all assets in one fund and some investors believe they do not allow for a [[tax-efficient fund placement]] of each individual asset class. <ref>[https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=287967 Additional aspects of tax efficiency and a one fund portfolio are discussed here.]</ref><ref>The subject of tax efficient placement of assets is complex and often the optimal result depends on the specific assumptions involved, such as the applicable bond interest rate, the equity dividend and capital distribution rates, using risk adjust after tax returns, etc. Refer to the tax efficient placement of assets page for a more thorough discussion.</ref>
These funds all have an increasing and/or large allocation to bonds. Because bond fund distributions are considered ordinary income (that is, they are taxed at your [[marginal tax rate]]), you will pay higher taxes than a stock fund (taxed at a lower [[Capital gains distribution|capital gains rate]]).
In addition, in many instances, such as with Vanguard, the equity distributions from the target date funds are not tax managed and are less tax efficient than comparable component index funds.<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/another-capital-gains-season-forget-vanguards-target-date Morningstar-Another Capital Gains Season to Forget for Vanguard’s Target-Date]</ref> A [[fund of funds]] must pass on all capital gains distributed by the underlying funds, and cannot use the losses. It may also have to pay out its own gains when it rebalances, although many funds of funds can use new investments to rebalance and thus avoid distributing gains. Thus a fund of funds is more likely to distribute capital gains than a balanced fund with similar holdings.
For the above reasons, in most circumstances, the most suitable location for target date funds is in tax-advantaged accounts such that tax efficiency becomes less relevant.
If you expect to be in a low tax bracket for the intended holding period, these funds might be appropriate in a taxable account. Investors having both taxable and tax-advantaged accounts may be better served by splitting their equity and fixed income allocations, concentrating on tax-efficient asset location.
There are now ETF versions of Target Date Funds, such as [https://www.ishares.com/us/resources/tools/target-date-fund-finder#/home Blackrock ishares Lifepath series.]. These are relatively new and with any such offering there is always the possibility if they do not gather enough interest they can be subsequently closed, leading to unwanted potential capital gains recognition.<ref>[https://www.morningstar.com/funds/new-era-retirement-savings Morningstar - A New Era for Retirement Savings]</ref>
As of 2010, the Regulated Investment Company Modernization Act of 2010 allows funds of funds to pass on the [[foreign tax credit]] from the individual funds to their shareholders.<ref>[[Fund of funds#Taxes]]</ref><ref>[https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=125475 Bogleheads - Foreign Tax Credit for Funds of Funds thread]</ref>
Note: Taxes considerations are ''secondary'' to setting your desired [[asset allocation]].
===Possible unsatisfactory allocation choices=== Depending on your personal preferences, a target date fund's asset allocations could be unsatisfactory. For example: * Some providers include active funds, and you may not want this. * Providers sometimes change the allocation of their target date funds. If you do not like the new allocation, you might find it awkward to sell the fund, especially in a taxable account where you might face taxes. * Certain asset classes may not be represented, for example, high-yield bonds and commodities. Funds often only add inflation-protected securities to their allocation as the target date nears. * The funds' asset class weightings do not suit all tastes. ** Target date funds have a fixed allocation to domestic and international. If you want to decide your domestic/international allocation yourself, you might not find this allocation satisfactory. ** The portfolios use market cap weighted funds, so they are inappropriate if you plan to [[Value Tilting - Stock | value "tilt"]] your stock allocation. ** If you plan to hold equity REITs in proportion to the weighting of commercial property in the economy, funds weight REITs allocations only to the extent they appear in Total Stock Market Index.
===Expenses=== Historically, some mutual fund companies' target date fund [[expense ratios]] may have included an additional expense ratio, on top of the expense ratios of the underlying funds. Also there are currently versions of target dates funds that use underlying active funds with expense ratios higher than index funds. Finally some small company 401k plans may assess higher expense ratios on target date offerings.
As noted in the advantages section, in recent years index versions of target date funds have become more widely available with significantly lower expense ratios.
==Vanguard target retirement funds== {{main|Vanguard target retirement funds}} Vanguard builds its target retirement funds primarily with index funds. They suit investors who want indexed portfolios and look for low-cost investments. In 2022 Vanguard lowered its average retirement account expense ratio to 0.08%.<ref>[https://corporate.vanguard.com/content/corporatesite/us/en/corp/who-we-are/pressroom/vanguard-returns-value-to-shareholders-with-lower-costs-for-target-retirement-funds.html Vanguard Returns Value to Shareholders with Lower Costs for Target Retirement Funds]</ref>

{{Balanced funds}} [[Category:Balanced funds]]

{{US|reason=harmful|non-US_link=[[Simple non-US portfolios]]}}
On February 6, 2013 Vanguard announced the creation of '''four fund portfolios''' by adding a strategic allocation of [[Developed market bonds|international hedged bonds]] to the firm's series of target date ([[Vanguard Target Retirement Funds|Target Retirement]]) and target risk ([[Vanguard LifeStrategy Funds|LifeStrategy]]) funds.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://pressroom.vanguard.com/content/press_release/2013.02.06_Vanguard_to_Further_Diversify_Target_Retirement_Funds.html| title=Vanguard to Further Diversify Target Retirement Funds| date=February 6, 2013| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190117081102/https://pressroom.vanguard.com/content/news/2013.02.06_Vanguard_to_Further_Diversify_Target_Retirement_Funds.html| archive-date=January 17, 2019}}</ref> These funds are commonly offered by [[Employer Retirement Plans Overview|employer provided plans]], where they are often default investment options; in [[529 plans|529 college savings plans]]; and in [[IRA|individual retirement arrangements]].
The allocation plan adds the Vanguard International Bond Index fund to the portfolio asset mix. This bond fund is hedged to reduce currency risk.
==Three fund and four fund portfolios==
Prior to the addition of an international bond fund to the target date and target risk funds, the allocation of these balanced portfolios were versions of the very popular [[Three-Fund Portfolio|three fund portfolio]],<ref>{{forum link| t=88005| title=The Three Fund Portfolio}}</ref> which consists of three broad asset class index funds: * Total U.S. stock market index fund * Total international stock index fund * Total U.S. bond index fund
The four-fund portfolio that Vanguard is now using consists of the following broad asset class index funds: * Total U.S. stock market index fund * Total international stock index fund * Total U.S. bond index fund * Total international bond index fund
From 2013 - 2015 Vanguard allocated 30% of a portfolio's stock allocation to international stocks and allocated 20% of a portfolio's nominal bond allocation to international bonds.
Beginning in 2015, Vanguard increased the international allocations to the four fund portfolios. International stock allocations increased from 30% to 40% of a portfolio's stock allocation. International bonds increased from 20% to 30% of a portfolio's nominal bond allocation. The allocation changes began in the second quarter of 2015 and were completed before year-end.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://institutional.vanguard.com/VGApp/iip/site/institutional/researchcommentary/article/NewsInstinfo022615QA| title=2015 changes to Target Retirement Funds, Q&A| publisher=Vanguard Institutional| date=February 26, 2015| accessdate=28 February 2015}}{{dead link}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://institutional.vanguard.com/VGApp/iip/site/institutional/researchcommentary/article/NewsInstinfo022615| title=Expanded target-date lineup, more diversification| publisher=Vanguard| date=February 26, 2015| accessdate=August 9, 2015}}{{dead link}}</ref>

{{Balanced funds}}
[[Category:Balanced funds]] [[Category:Portfolios]]

{{US|reason=harmful|non-US_link=[[Simple non-US portfolios]]}} {{See also|Vanguard funds: life strategy funds vs target retirement funds}}
The '''{{PAGENAME}}''' are lifecycle offerings, providing investors with a variety of highly diversified all-in-one portfolios. The products are structured as [[Fund of funds | funds-of-funds]], charging only [[Acquired fund fees and expenses|weighted averages]] of the [[Expense ratios | expense ratios]] associated with the underlying [[Indexing|index]] funds.<ref>[https://personal.vanguard.com/us/funds/vanguard/LifeStrategyList Lifestrategy Funds], Vanguard official site</ref>
LifeStrategy funds are cheap by any reasonable standard. In contrast to the Vanguard series of similar one fund diversified portfolios, [[ Vanguard Target Retirement Funds |target retirement funds]], which use a gradual shifting strategic asset allocation over time, the LifeStrategy funds have a fixed target asset allocation.
Vanguard considers the LifeStrategy funds to be'' target risk funds'', in contrast to ''target date'' target retirement funds.
==Four portfolios== While the funds are ostensibly designed for investors having a certain level of risk tolerance (approximately), and are typically considered to be retirement accumulation or retirement decumulation vehicles, you can use them for other goals, depending on your objectives. For example, the LifeStrategy funds are often investment options in many state run [[529 plans]] designed for funding college education expenses.
There are four LifeStrategy funds:
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- ! Fund !! Symbol !! Vanguard link !! Morningstar link |- | align="left"| Vanguard LifeStrategy Income Fund || VASIX || [{{vf|0723}} link] || {{mf|VASIX|link}} |- | align="left"| Vanguard LifeStrategy Conservative Growth Fund || VSCGX || [{{vf|0724}} link] || {{mf|VSCGX|link}} |- | align="left"| Vanguard LifeStrategy Moderate Growth Fund || VSMGX || [{{vf|0914}} link] ||{{mf|VSMGX|link}} |- | align="left"| Vanguard LifeStrategy Growth Fund || VASGX || [{{vf|0122}} link] || {{mf|VASGX|link}} |}
==Fund allocations==
On February 26, 2015, Vanguard announced an increase in the funds' international equity allocation from 30% to 40% of equity exposure, and an increase in the international fixed income allocation from 20% to 30% of nominal fixed income exposure.<ref>[https://personal.vanguard.com/us/insights/article/fund-announcement-02262015 Vanguard enhances diversification for target date funds and other all-in-one funds] 26 Feb 2015</ref>
The tables below show allocations of the funds after the 2015 reset. The reallocation of fund assets was completed by the end of 2015.<ref>[https://institutional.vanguard.com/VGApp/iip/site/institutional/researchcommentary/article/NewsInstinfo022615QA 2015 changes to Target Retirement Funds, Q&A], Vanguard Institutional, February 26, 2015. Reviewed 28 February 2015.</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+ LifeStrategy funds target asset mix ! Holding !! Growth [[File:LSGrowth2015.png|200px]] !! Moderate growth [[File:LSModerate2015.png ‎|200px]] !! Conservative growth [[File:LSconservative2015.png|200px]] !! Income [[File:LSincome2015.png|220px]] |- ! style="text-align:left;"|US stocks | align="center"|48% ||align="center"| 36% ||align="center"|24% ||align="center"|12% |- ! style="text-align:left;"|International stocks | align="center"| 32% ||align="center"| 24% ||align="center"| 16% ||align="center"| 8% |- ! style="text-align:left;"|US Bonds - Intermediate term | align="center"| 14% || align="center"|28% || align="center"|42% ||align="center"| 56% |- ! style="text-align:left;"|International bonds - intermediate term | align="center"| 6% || align="center"|12% || align="center"|18% ||align="center"| 24% |- |}
==Drawbacks== While LifeStrategy Funds provide very simple diversification for their shareholders, there are some reasonable criticisms.
===Tax inefficiency=== Because the LifeStrategy Funds all have a significant allocation to taxable bonds, they are most suitable for investors holding their entire portfolios in tax-advantaged accounts. If you have both taxable and tax-advantaged accounts you are generally better served by splitting your equity and fixed income allocations, concentrating on tax-efficient asset location. Among the tax considerations are:
* When held in a tax-advantaged account, stocks lose any special benefits they have in a taxable account.<ref group="note"> Potential advantages for holding stocks in a taxable account include:
* Tax-deferred accounts convert long-term capital gains into ordinary income upon distribution; tax rates on long-term capital gains have been, at most times, lower than ordinary income rates. * Qualified dividends are currently taxed at a lower rate. * Long-term capital gains are only due when realized, giving another way to defer taxes. * Ability to harvest losses. * Ability to donate appreciated shares to charity, avoiding all taxes. * Estate planning; there is a potential for stepped-up cost basis upon death.</ref> * In a taxable account the bond dividends will get taxed annually at ordinary income rates; when held in tax advantaged accounts this tax can be deferred. * By holding a balanced fund in a taxable account the investor loses the option to [[Tax loss harvesting | harvest losses]] of individual asset classes. * The fund has a history of changing asset allocation and targeted asset classes. If the change is not appropriate for you, selling your holding could create an unwanted large capital gains tax liability.
===Allocation choices=== Depending on your personal preferences, the LifeStrategy Funds' asset allocations could be unsatisfactory. For example: * Certain asset classes are not represented. For example, inflation-protected securities and commodities are entirely absent. * The funds' asset class weightings do not suit all tastes. If you aim to match global asset allocations, 60% of equities are domestic, which is above the U.S. share by world market capitalization. The portfolios employ asset class funds that are market cap weighted, so the funds are not appropriate if you want to [[Value Tilting - Stock | value "tilt"]] the equity allocation of your U.S. stock holdings. If you want to hold equity REITs in proportion to the weighting of commercial property in the economy, the funds' REITs allocations are represented only to the extent they appear in Total Stock Market Index.
==History== Vanguard launched all four LifeStrategy Funds on September 30, 1994. Since then the fund has made numerous changes in asset class selections and portfolio allocations.
===Changes in 2011=== Vanguard announced a change in the funds' investment policy on September 30, 2011.<ref group="note"> From 1994-2011 the LifeStrategy funds asset allocations were implemented with these Vanguard fund portfolios: *Vanguard Total Stock Market Index Fund *Vanguard Total International Stock Index Fund *Vanguard Asset Allocation Fund *Vanguard Total Bond Market II Index Fund *Vanguard Short-Term Investment Grade Bond Fund</ref> The funds adopted an all-index fund portfolio and implemented the change across several months following September 2011.<ref>[https://personal.vanguard.com/us/insights/article/fund-announcementB-09302011 LifeStrategy Funds to adopt all-index approach], September 30, 2011.</ref> The portfolio allocation of the funds after the adoption of the all-index fund approach is shown in the following table:
{| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" align="center" |+ style="white-space:nowrap; border:1px solid; padding:3px;" | LifeStrategy funds target asset mix ! Holding !! Growth[[File:LifeStrategy Growth Fund.png|200px]] !! Moderate growth[[File:LifeStrategy Moderate Growth Fund.png|200px]] !! Conservative growth[[File:LifeStrategy Conservative Growth Fund.png|200px]] !! Income[[File:LifeStrategy Income Fund.png|200px]] |- ! style="text-align:left;"| US stocks | align="center"|56% ||align="center"| 42% ||align="center"|28% ||align="center"|14% |- ! style="text-align:left;"| International stocks | align="center"| 24% ||align="center"| 18% ||align="center"| 12% ||align="center"| 6% |- ! style="text-align:left;"| US bonds - intermediate term | align="center"| 20% || align="center"|40% || align="center"|60% ||align="center"| 80% |- |}
===Changes in 2013===
On February 6, 2013, Vanguard announced the addition of a fourth asset class, [[Developed market bonds|international bonds]], to the LifeStrategy fund asset allocation matrix.<ref> [https://personal.vanguard.com/us/insights/article/fund-announcement-02062013 We're introducing Vanguard Total International Bond Index Fund] </ref>. The new asset allocation changes were completed on May 31, 2013.
The LifeStrategy funds had the following target asset mix, implemented with these Vanguard fund portfolios: *Vanguard Total Stock Market Index Fund *Vanguard Total International Stock Index Fund *Vanguard Total Bond Market II Index Fund *Vanguard Total International Bond Index Fund {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" align="center" |+ style="white-space:nowrap; border:1px solid; padding:3px;" | LifeStrategy Funds Target Asset Mix ! Income[[File:Chart 4(1).png|220px]] |- ! style="text-align:left;"| US stocks | align="center"|56% ||align="center"| 42% ||align="center"|28% ||align="center"|14% |- ! style="text-align:left;"| International stocks | align="center"| 24% ||align="center"| 18% ||align="center"| 12% ||align="center"| 6% |- ! style="text-align:left;"| US bonds - intermediate term | align="center"| 16% || align="center"|32% || align="center"|48% ||align="center"| 64% |- ! style="text-align:left;"| International bonds - intermediate term | align="center"| 4% || align="center"|8% || align="center"|12% ||align="center"| 16% |- |}

See the [[#Fund allocations|Fund allocations]] section.
